Objectives: Students will develop the ability to competently undertake safe and autonomous therapeutic management of patients, including the ability to design, implement and monitor appropriate management programmes. The course aims also to equip students with the skills to incorporate ocular therapeutics into their professional practice and to work in an integrated way with other health professionals.


Brief Curriculum: This supervised clinical course is designed to provide guided practical experience in the therapeutic management of ocular disease. The course comprises clinical training in a range of settings, including primary, secondary and tertiary centres.


Students may be required to attend compulsory external clinical placements which require additional costs to cover travel and accommodation.

Supervisor assessments occur during clinical rotations. Students are required to achieve a 50% or higher grade in the Supervisor Evaluation section to pass the course. Performance will be judged against competencies. Feedback will be given during and following placements.

Case reports will be assessed on:

1.Diagnosis (Signs, symptoms, pathophysiology and epidemiology)

2. Differential (Clear reasons for including and excluding all important differentials)

3. Management (Non-medical; medical with frequency, concentration, duration, instructions, pharmacology, side effects and contraindications; surgical)

4.Prognosis (Natural history, expected outcome of interventions, long term monitoring, review periods, advice to patient)

5. Literature (Statements referenced, major clinical trials and established guidelines)

Perimetry Assignment:Perimetry assignment quality is assessed with respect to relevant critical competencies.

Referral letter quality is assessed with respect to relevant critical competencies.

contentlets.description:
Objectives: Students will develop the ability to competently undertake safe and autonomous therapeutic management of patients, including the ability to design, implement and monitor appropriate management programmes. The course aims also to equip students with the skills to incorporate ocular therapeutics into their professional practice and to work in an integrated way with other health professionals.

Brief Curriculum: This supervised clinical course is designed to provide guided practical experience in the therapeutic management of ocular disease. The course comprises clinical training in a range of settings, including primary, secondary and tertiary centres.

Students may be required to attend compulsory external clinical placements which require additional costs to cover travel and accommodation.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"OPTM8514","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"4 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"OPTM8514 - Optometry Research Project","description":"

Modern optometrists need to be able to understand clinical and vision science research. This course introduces students to research and the scientific method. The course covers the following: a literature review, critical analysis of the literature, developing a hypothesis, experimental design, ethical considerations, and the research process. Students will work in pairs, under the supervision and guidance of a member of academic staff, visiting staff, staff optometrists, postgraduate research students or external researchers, to develop a realistic research proposal.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"42f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96191b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Supervisor Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Each student will be assessed by the supervisor on the following:

  • Involvement and engagement in conduct of project
  • Contribution to data collection, collation and statistical analysis
  • Attendance at project meetings
  • Contributions to seminar and report preparation
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"06f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8ef599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"31f559bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

At the end of semester students will be required to present their scientific work as a poster and conduct a rapid fire 5 - minute presentation at a school conference. Academic staff will assess the quality of the scientific work and presentation particularly for their scientific content, communication clarity and style, evidence of teamwork

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"06f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8ef599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c6f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bdf559bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"55","description":"

This major assessment will include two components. The first will be a literature review. The literature review will be marked by the supervisor based on:

  • Demonstrated knowledge of topic area
  • Content and organisation, coverage of key issues
  • Depth and breadth of analysis and discussion
  • Correctness and scope of references
  • Appropriate style and presentation

The second component is a written research report which details the student's independent research. The report should be no longer than 10,000 words, and should be prepared as a journal submission in this field of research. This generally involves an abstract, introduction, methods, results and discussion. Variations of this format are allowed given disciplinary variations regarding how research is to be reported.

The written research report is to be submitted at the end of semester. This report will be marked by two independent assessors in the school or elsewhere when expertise is needed. This assessment is based on:

  • Demonstrated knowledge of topic area
  • Depth and breath of discussion
  • Content and organisation of report, coverage of key issues
  • Appropriate use of figures and tables
  • Correctness and appropriate use of reference
  • Organisation, clarity and format in appropriate scientific style and presentation.
  • Appropriate use of figures and tables

If applicable for the research that will be undertaken, students will work with their supervisor to write and submit an ethics application to the relevant ethics committee at UNSW. Supervisors will provide feedback to students in terms of draft applications. If an ethics application is not required, student will undertake a compulsory online quiz to test  their knowledge of ethics within research. Passing this quiz with a mark of 70% or more is required before the students present their research at the end of year research presentations

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"06f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"42f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8ef599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c6f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f5f559bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/OPTM8514.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Students will work in pairs, under the supervision and guidance of a member of academic staff, visiting staff, staff optometrists, postgraduate research students or external researchers, to develop a realistic research proposal.

Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"OPTM8518","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"OPTM8518 - Optometry Research Project A","description":"

Modern optometrists need to be able to understand clinical and vision science research. This course introduces students to research and the scientific method. The course covers the following: a literature review, critical analysis of the literature, developing a hypothesis, experimental design, ethical considerations, and the research process. Students will work in pairs, under the supervision and guidance of a member of academic staff, visiting staff, staff optometrists, postgraduate research students or external researchers, to develop a realistic research proposal. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"971c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Supervisor Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Each student will be assessed by the supervisor on the following: 

• Involvement and engagement in project planning 

• Contribution to pilot studies and developing research methods 

• Attendance at project meetings 

• Contributions to preparation of literature review and ethics application

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0f1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8f1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"931c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3e1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The literature review will be marked by the supervisor based on: 

• Demonstrated knowledge of topic area 

• Content and organisation, coverage of key issues 

• Depth and breadth of analysis and discussion 

• Correctness and scope of references 

• Appropriate style and presentation 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0f1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1b1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"571c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8f1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"931c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cb1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"761c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Ethics Application","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will be required to work with their supervisor to write and submit an ethics application to the relevant ethics committee at UNSW. Supervisors will provide feedback to students in terms of draft applications. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8f1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"931c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cb1c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f21c70f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/OPTM8518.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"OPTM8521 - Clinical Contact Lenses","description":"

Objectives: Further development of the clinical skills needed to competently examine patients in optometric practice, and recommend appropriate treatment and strategies for patients presenting for eyecare.


Brief Curriculum: This course  comprises supervised clinical placements o in the following advanced areas of Optometry practice: contact lenses and  advanced contact lenses.


Students may be required to attend compulsory clinical placements during the mid-year recess.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3ee389a9db075050358b403c3a961931","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Clinical Skills Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"65","description":"

Assessment will be ongoing throughout semester Feedback will be given during and following clinical sessions by the Clinical Supervisors

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"72e389a9db075050358b403c3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76e389a9db075050358b403c3a961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0fe389a9db075050358b403c3a9619ef","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written Case Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will be required to complete a written case report based on patients seen during their clinical rotation. The written report should demonstrate knowledge in contact lens fitting and the ability to critically appraise scientific literature. Feedback will be given following marking in the examination period.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"72e389a9db075050358b403c3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76e389a9db075050358b403c3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7ee389a9db075050358b403c3a961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7ee389a9db075050358b403c3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7ee389a9db075050358b403c3a961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bee389a9db075050358b403c3a9619e6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journals","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

Students will be required to complete a journal that reflects on their clinical experience.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"76e389a9db075050358b403c3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76e389a9db075050358b403c3a961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c3e389a9db075050358b403c3a9619f3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"5","description":"

An oral examination on contact lens knowledge and clinical understanding will be conducted during the final 2 weeks of the clinical rotation. Assessment will be by the Clinical Supervisor.

contentlets.description:
Objectives: Further development of the clinical skills needed to competently examine patients in optometric practice, and recommend appropriate treatment and strategies for patients presenting for eyecare.

Brief Curriculum: This course  comprises supervised clinical placements o in the following advanced areas of Optometry practice: contact lenses and  advanced contact lenses.

Students may be required to attend compulsory clinical placements during the mid-year recess.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"OPTM8522 - Clinical Optometry 5B","description":"Objectives: Further development of the clinical skills needed to competently examine patients in optometric practice, and recommend appropriate treatment and strategies for patients presenting for primary eye care.

contentlets.description:
Objectives: Further development of the clinical skills needed to competently examine patients in optometric practice, and recommend appropriate treatment and strategies for patients presenting for primary eye care.

Brief Curriculum: To enhance clinical experience in providing primary eye care. The emphasis in this course is the diagnosis and management of visual problems. Students will be required to attend compulsory clinical placements outside the standard teaching period. Students will be required to attend external clinical placements which require additional costs to cover travel and accommodation. Students must also complete a minimum of 18 days of approved work experience (Stage 5 Preceptorship placement) and submit satisfactory written reports on this placement.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"OPTM8523 - Clinical Ocular Therapy 5B","description":"

Objectives: Students will develop the ability to competently undertake safe and autonomous therapeutic management of patients, including the ability to design, implement and monitor appropriate management programmes. The course aims also to equip students with the skills to incorporate ocular therapeutics into their professional practice and to work in an integrated way with other health professionals.


Brief Curriculum: This supervised clinical course is designed to provide guided practical experience in the therapeutic management of ocular disease. The course comprises clinical training in a range of settings, including primary, secondary and tertiary centres.


Students may be required to attend compulsory external clinical placements which require additional costs to cover travel and accommodation.


This clinical placement course appears to have a high number of contact hours. This is due to the nature of the course and are required for the optometry program  to maintain its accreditation by the Optometry Council of Australia and New Zealand (OCANZ).

Case reports will be assessed on:

 1.Diagnosis (Signs, symptoms, pathophysiology and epidemiology)

2. Differential (Clear reasons for including and excluding all important differentials)

3. Management (Non-medical; medical with frequency, concentration, duration, instructions, pharmacology, side effects and contraindications; surgical)

4.Prognosis (Natural history, expected outcome of interventions, long term monitoring, review periods, advice to patient)

5. Literature (Statements referenced, major clinical trials and established guidelines)

Perimetry Assignment:Perimetry assignment quality is assessed with respect to relevant critical competencies.

Referral letter quality is assessed with respect to relevant critical competencies.

contentlets.description:
Objectives: Students will develop the ability to competently undertake safe and autonomous therapeutic management of patients, including the ability to design, implement and monitor appropriate management programmes. The course aims also to equip students with the skills to incorporate ocular therapeutics into their professional practice and to work in an integrated way with other health professionals.

Brief Curriculum: This supervised clinical course is designed to provide guided practical experience in the therapeutic management of ocular disease. The course comprises clinical training in a range of settings, including primary, secondary and tertiary centres.

Students may be required to attend compulsory external clinical placements which require additional costs to cover travel and accommodation.

This clinical placement course appears to have a high number of contact hours. This is due to the nature of the course and are required for the optometry program  to maintain its accreditation by the Optometry Council of Australia and New Zealand (OCANZ).

Objectives: Students will develop the ability to competently undertake safe and autonomous therapeutic management of patients, including the ability to design, implement and monitor appropriate management programmes. The course aims also to equip students with the skills to incorporate ocular therapeutics into their professional practice and to work in an integrated way with other health professionals.


Brief Curriculum: This supervised clinical course is designed to provide guided practical experience in the therapeutic management of ocular disease. The course comprises clinical training in a range of settings, including primary, secondary and tertiary centres.


Students may be required to attend compulsory external clinical placements which require additional costs to cover travel and accommodation.


This clinical placement course appears to have a high number of contact hours. This is due to the nature of the course and are required for the optometry program  to maintain its accreditation by the Optometry Council of Australia and New Zealand (OCANZ).

Case reports will be assessed on:

 1.Diagnosis (Signs, symptoms, pathophysiology and epidemiology)

2. Differential (Clear reasons for including and excluding all important differentials)

3. Management (Non-medical; medical with frequency, concentration, duration, instructions, pharmacology, side effects and contraindications; surgical)

4.Prognosis (Natural history, expected outcome of interventions, long term monitoring, review periods, advice to patient)

5. Literature (Statements referenced, major clinical trials and established guidelines)

Perimetry Assignment:Perimetry assignment quality is assessed with respect to relevant critical competencies.

Referral letter quality is assessed with respect to relevant critical competencies.

Optometry Research Project B","description":"

This course continues to develop the skills learnt in OPTM8518. Students assemble the required materials, subjects and equipment, and conduct the experiment they proposed in OPTM8518. The data are analysed using the appropriate statistical methods, and a publication-quality written report is submitted. Each group is also required to present the results of their research at the annual student research presentation day, as a quick-fire (3-minute) presentation and as a scientific poster. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"442cb0f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195d","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This report will be marked based on:

• Organisation, clarity and format in appropriate scientific style 

• Content of report, coverage of key issues 

• Depth and breadth of discussion 

• Appropriate use of figures and tables 

• Correctness and appropriate use of references 

The written research report is the major assessment component of the honours year that reports the student's independent research. The report should be no longer than 10,000 words, and should be prepared as a journal submission in this field of research. This generally involves an abstract, introduction, methods, results and discussion. Though variations of this format are allowed given disciplinary variations regarding how research is to be reported.

The written research report is to be submitted at the end of semester. This report will be marked by two independent assessors in the school or elsewhere when expertise is needed. This assessment is based on:

  • Depth and breath of discussion
  • Content of report, coverage of key issues
  • Appropriate use of figures and tables
  • Correctness and appropriate use of reference
  • Organisation, clarity and format in appropriate scientific style.

Course Convener returns the report with marks and assessor's comments

At the end of semester students will be required to present their scientific work as a Poster and conduct a rapid fire 5 - minute presentation at a school conference. 

Academic staff will assess the quality of the scientific work and presentation particularly for their scientific content, communication clarity and style, evidence of teamwork

Each student will be assessed by the supervisor on the following: 

• Involvement and engagement in conduct of project 

• Contribution to data collection, collation and statistical analysis 

• Attendance at project meetings 

• Contributions to seminar and report preparation 

• Evidence of teamwork
